entry.title: cheatsheet/apt
entry.content:
Cheatsheet apt (Advanced Package Tool)

Advanced Package Tool (or APT), the main command-line package manager for Debian and its derivatives. It provides command-line tools for searching, managing and querying information about packages, as well as low-level access to all features provided by the libapt-pkg and libapt-inst libraries which higher-level package managers can depend upon.

Basic apt commands

# Atualizar a lista de pacotes disponíveis
sudo apt update

# Atualizar todos os pacotes instalados
sudo apt upgrade

# Atualizar o sistema inteiro, incluindo pacotes que exigem novas dependências
sudo apt dist-upgrade

# Instalar um pacote
sudo apt install nome-do-pacote

# Remover um pacote (o pacote é desinstalado, mas as configurações permanecem)
sudo apt remove nome-do-pacote

# Remover um pacote junto com suas configurações
sudo apt purge nome-do-pacote

# Procurar um pacote pelo nome ou descrição
apt search termo-de-busca

# Exibir informações detalhadas sobre um pacote
apt show nome-do-pacote

# Listar todos os pacotes instalados
dpkg --list

# Listar pacotes específicos
dpkg --list | grep termo-de-busca

# Listar pacotes disponíveis para atualização
apt list --upgradable

# Mostrar as dependências de um pacote
apt depends nome-do-pacote

# Verificar se um pacote específico está instalado
dpkg -l | grep nome-do-pacote

# Limpar o cache de pacotes baixados (libera espaço em disco)
sudo apt clean

# Remover pacotes órfãos (pacotes que não são mais necessários)
sudo apt autoremove

# Verificar a integridade dos pacotes instalados
sudo apt check

# Corrigir problemas de dependências quebradas
sudo apt --fix-broken install

# Bloquear a versão de um pacote para evitar atualizações automáticas
sudo apt-mark hold nome-do-pacote

# Desbloquear um pacote previamente bloqueado
sudo apt-mark unhold nome-do-pacote

# Visualizar o histórico de atualizações
less /var/log/apt/history.log

entry.title: development/golang/logs
entry.content:
Logs

Libraries

Standard Library (log)

package main

import (
    "log"
)

func main() {
    log.Println("This is a log message using the standard library")
	log.Printf("Debug: %s\n", "Detailed information for debugging purposes")
	log.Println("Info: Application started")
	log.Printf("Warning: %s\n", "Potential issue")
	log.Fatalf("Error: %s\n", "Recoverable error, application continues running")
}

Logrus

//go get -u github.com/sirupsen/logrus
package main

import (
 "github.com/sirupsen/logrus"
)

func main() {
 logrus.SetFormatter(&logrus.JSONFormatter{})
 logrus.SetLevel(logrus.InfoLevel)

 logrus.Info("Application started")
 logrus.Warn("Potential issue")
 logrus.Fatal("Critical error, shutting down")
}

Zap

package main

import (
    "go.uber.org/zap"
)

func main() {
    logger, _ := zap.NewProduction()
    defer logger.Sync()

    logger.Info("This is a log message using Zap")
}

Zerolog

package main

import (
    "github.com/rs/zerolog"
    "github.com/rs/zerolog/log"
)

func main() {
    log.Info().Msg("This is a log message using Zerolog")
}

Below is an example of an audit strategy with logs, sending to Elasticsearch

package main

import (
	"context"
	"crypto/tls"
	"encoding/json"
	"fmt"
	"log"
	"net/http"
	"strings"
	"time"

	"github.com/elastic/go-elasticsearch/esapi"
	"github.com/elastic/go-elasticsearch/v8"
)

var (
	user = "elastic"
	pass = "dSIZRsJR+c8ygXi_Laah"

	esClient *elasticsearch.Client
)

type AuditLogEntry struct {
	Actor   string      `json:"actor"`
	Action  string      `json:"action"`
	Module  string      `json:"module"`
	When    time.Time   `json:"when"`
	Details interface{} `json:"details"`
}

func initElasticsearchClient() {
	cfg := elasticsearch.Config{
		Addresses: []string{
			"https://localhost:9200",
		},
		Transport: &http.Transport{
			MaxIdleConnsPerHost:   10,
			ResponseHeaderTimeout: time.Second,
			TLSClientConfig:       &tls.Config{InsecureSkipVerify: true},
		},
		Username: user,
		Password: pass,
	}

	var err error
	esClient, err = elasticsearch.NewClient(cfg)
	if err != nil {
		log.Fatalf("Error creating the client: %s", err)
	}
}

func logAndSendToElasticsearch(entry AuditLogEntry) {
	body, err := json.Marshal(entry)
	if err != nil {
		log.Fatalf("Error marshaling entry to JSON: %s", err)
	}

	req := esapi.IndexRequest{
		Index:        "audit_logs",
		DocumentType: "_doc",
		DocumentID:   "",
		Body:         strings.NewReader(string(body)),
		Refresh:      "true",
	}

	resp, err := req.Do(context.Background(), esClient)
	fmt.Println(resp)
	if err != nil {
		log.Fatalf("Error sending entry to Elasticsearch: %s", err)
	}
}

func logAuditEvent(actor string, action string, module string, details interface{}) AuditLogEntry {
	entry := AuditLogEntry{
		Actor:   actor,
		Action:  action,
		Module:  module,
		When:    time.Now(),
		Details: details,
	}

	return entry
}

func eventExample() {
	entry := logAuditEvent("Vinícius", "password_change", "User Settings", "Changed password for security reasons")
	logAndSendToElasticsearch(entry)
}

func main() {
	initElasticsearchClient()

	eventExample()
}

Json format log

package main

import (
 "encoding/json"
 "log"
 "time"
)

func main() {
 logData := map[string]interface{}{
  "event":     "ApplicationStarted",
  "severity":  "Info",
  "message":   "Application started",
  "timestamp": time.Now(),
 }

 logJSON, _ := json.Marshal(logData)
 log.Println(string(logJSON))
}

References

https://medium.com/@alameerashraf/building-an-audit-log-system-for-a-go-application-ce131dc21394 https://www.elastic.co/pt/downloads/elasticsearch https://www.elastic.co/pt/downloads/kibana https://medium.com/wisemonks/foundations-of-golang-logging-a-comprehensive-primer-754c8477bc34

entry.title: development/golang/generics
entry.content:
Generics

Generics in Go is a programming language feature introduced to enhance the flexibility and reusability of code. The primary goal is to allow developers to write functions and data structures that can operate on different data types without sacrificing type safety. With the introduction of generics, Go enables the creation of functions and data structures that are not tied to a specific data type, allowing for more versatile and reusable code. This is particularly beneficial when dealing with algorithms and data structures that need to work with various types of data. Generics in Go are implemented using type parameters, allowing developers to define functions and data structures that can work with any type. This reduces code duplication and promotes cleaner, more modular code. Developers can use generics to write more flexible and concise code, as functions and data structures can be written once and applied to different types without sacrificing type safety.

Generics have everything to do with Constraints and Interfaces. Before version 1.18(something), to create the Any type, an empty interface was used, represented by interface{}.

func Print(a ...interface{}) (n int, err error)

Before generics existed

To discover the type, a switch statement was used:

package main

import "fmt"

func something(x interface{}) {
	switch idk := x.(type) {
	case int:
		fmt.Println("eh int:", idk)
	case string:
		fmt.Println("eh string:", idk)
	default:
		fmt.Println("eh invalido", idk)
	}
}

func main() {
	something("brazil")
	something(1337)
	something(12.123)
}

After generics was implemented

package main

import "fmt"

type UserTest1 struct {
	name string
	age  int16
}

type UserTest2 struct {
	documentNumber string
	address        string
}

func userTest[T UserTest1 | UserTest2](user T) {
	fmt.Println(user)
	fmt.Println(user)
}

func identity[T any](arg T) T {
	return arg
}

func anyType(arg any) any {
	return arg
}

func main() {

	u1 := UserTest1{
		name: "Mario",
		age:  29,
	}
	userTest(u1)

	// num := 10
	// userTest(num)

	out1 := identity[string]("test")
	fmt.Println(out1)
	out2 := identity[int16](1234)
	fmt.Println(out2)

	out3 := anyType(1234)
	fmt.Println(out3)
	out4 := anyType("test")
	fmt.Println(out4)
}

And to make comparisons between variables of type Any? Below is an ugly way to do it.

func main() {
	var value1 interface{} = 42
	var value2 interface{} = "42"

	if reflect.TypeOf(value1).Kind() == reflect.Int && reflect.TypeOf(value2).Kind() == reflect.String {
		convertedValue1 := value1.(int)
		convertedValue2 := value2.(string)

		if convertedValue1 == 42 && convertedValue2 == "42" {
			fmt.Println("As variáveis são iguais.")
		} else {
			fmt.Println("As variáveis são diferentes.")
		}
	} else {
		fmt.Println("Tipos incompatíveis para comparação.")
	}
}

Below is a more elegant implementation. It utilizes comparable

package main

import "fmt"

func anyTest[T comparable](arg1 T, arg2 T) {
	fmt.Println(arg1 == arg2)
}
func main() {
	anyTest(1, 2)
}

Comparison with < and >. It’s also possible to compare a primitive type with a defined type (using ~).

package main

import "fmt"

func test[T NumberTests](arg1 T, arg2 T) {
	fmt.Println(arg1 >= arg2)
}

func testInt[T ~int64](arg1 T, arg2 T) {
	fmt.Println(arg1 >= arg2)
}

type MyNum int64

type NumberTests interface {
	int64 | float64 | float32
}

type NumberIntTests interface {
	int64
}

func main() {
	test(3.2, 2.0)

	var iNum MyNum = 44
	testInt(iNum, 33)
}

It’s possible to use in the declaration of a type as well. Where it’s no longer necessary to define the type at the time of creation. For example:

package main

import "fmt"

type User[T any, B any] struct {
	name T
	age  B
}

func main() {

	userTest := User[string, int64]{
		name: "joao",
		age:  20,
	}

	fmt.Println(userTest)
}

References

  • https://gobyexample.com/generics
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nD_6L2PBfaE
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XcDnQvVCW78

entry.title: cheatsheet/docker
entry.content:
Cheatsheet docker

Docker is a powerful platform that has transformed the way software is developed, deployed, and managed. At its core, Docker utilizes containers, lightweight and portable units that package an application along with its dependencies and runtime environment. This revolutionary technology has streamlined the software development lifecycle, enhancing efficiency, scalability, and consistency across various environments.

Containers are encapsulated, isolated environments that include an application and its dependencies, ensuring consistency across different computing environments. Unlike traditional virtualization, which involves running multiple operating systems on a hypervisor, containers share the host operating system’s kernel. This makes them lightweight, faster to start, and more resource-efficient.

Basic commands for containers

 # Criacao container em background
docker run -d --name meu-container nginx:latest

 # Criacao container (nome deve ser unico) expondo a porta 80
docker run --name meu-container-nginx -p 8080:80 nginx:latest

# Listar containers em execucao
docker container ls 

# Listar os containers parados e em execucao (ALL)
docker container ls -a 

 # Parar um container (stopping)
docker stop meu-container

# Iniciar um container existente que esta parado
docker start meu-container 

# Ver os logs do container
docker logs meu-container 

# Entra no modo terminal interativo. Para sair usar CTRL+P CTRL+Q
docker exec -it meu-container bash 

# Remover um container (pode usar nome ou ID)
docker rm meu-container

# Executa o comando setando um Workdir(/tmp)
docker exec -it -w /tmp meu-container-nginx touch xD 

# Alterar nome de um container
docker rename meu-container-nginx meu-container-sagrado

# Mapeamento de volumes entre maquina host e container
docker run -d -v /tmp:/tmp nginx:latest 

# Mudar entrypoint
docker run -it --entrypoint sh soumyansh/demo.jar

Commands to copy files between host and container

# Copiar arquivo do host para o containe
docker cp /tmp/origin meu-container-nginx:/tmp r

# Testar o mapeamento de pastas entre container e maquina host
echo "by: apolzek" >> /tmp/whoami ; docker cp /tmp/whoami meu-container-nginx:/tmp; docker exec -it meu-container-nginx sh -c "cat /tmp/whoami"

# Copiar do container para host
docker cp meu-container-nginx:/tmp/whoami

Commands to view and limit resources

# Exibir um stream contínuo de estatísticas de uso de recursos de containers ativos
docker stats

# Executa um novo container a partir da imagem especificada, limitando-o a 2 núcleos de CPU e 1 GB de memória RAM
docker run --cpus=2 --memory=1g nome-da-imagem

# Inicia um novo container em segundo plano (-d), usando 2 núcleos de CPU e 6 MB de memória RAM
docker run -d --cpus=2 --memory=6MB nginx:latest

# Cia um novo container com o nome nginx-do-bem, limitando-o a 2 núcleos de CPU e 6 MB de memória RAM
docker run -d --name nginx-do-bem --cpus=2 --memory=6MB nginx:latest # cria container com limite de CPU e RAM

# Atualiza os limites do container chamado nginx-do-bem, definindo o limite de CPU para 2 núcleos, o limite de memória para 1 GB e o limite de swap para 1 GB
docker update --cpus 2 --memory 1024m --memory-swap 1024m nginx-do-bem # altera limites

# Atualiza apenas o limite de CPU do container chamado nginx-do-bem, reduzindo-o para 0.5 (ou seja, meio núcleo)
docker update --cpus=".5" nginx-do-bem # altera apenas liomite de CPU

Remove all images, containers or volumes

# Limpeza dos containers e volumes associados
docker system prune -a --volumes # 

# Remove todas as imagens
docker rmi $(docker images -q) -f 

 # Remove todos os containers
docker rm -f $(docker ps -aq)

# Remove todos os containers e volumes associados a ele
docker container rm -f $(docker container ls -qa); for i in $(docker volume ls | awk '{print $2}' | sed 1d); do docker volume rm -f $i; done

Basic build commands

# Este comando é usado para construir uma imagem Docker a partir de um arquivo Dockerfile localizado no caminho especificado
docker build -t minha-imagem:latest /caminho/do/Dockerfile

# Este comando remove a imagem Docker com o nome minha-imagem e a tag latest do sistema
docker rmi minha-imagem:latest

# Construir uma imagem Docker a partir de um arquivo Dockerfile local chamado Dockerfile.debug
docker build -f Dockerfile.debug .

Basic commands for images

docker image build
docker image history
docker image import
docker image inspect
docker image load
docker image ls
docker image prune
docker image pull
docker image push
docker image rm
docker image save
docker image tag
docker search debian # procurar uma imagem do registry
docker search --filter=stars=3 --no-trunc busybox
docker search --filter is-official=true --filter stars=3 busybox

Convert image to file and then import again

docker save -o nome_da_imagem.tar nome_da_imagem
docker load -i nome_da_imagem.tar

Docker on my local machine

/usr/bin/docker 
/etc/docker 
/usr/libexec/docker 
/usr/share/man/man1/docker.1.gz

/etc/docker/daemon.json

{
  "log-level": "info",
  "storage-driver": "overlay2",
  "data-root": "/var/lib/docker",
  "exec-opts": ["native.cgroupdriver=systemd"]
}

/lib/systemd/system/docker.service

[Unit]
Description=Docker Application Container Engine
Documentation=https://docs.docker.com
After=network-online.target firewalld.service containerd.service
Wants=network-online.target

[Service]
Type=notify
ExecStart=/usr/bin/dockerd -H fd:// --containerd=/run/containerd/containerd.sock
ExecReload=/bin/kill -s HUP $MAINPID
TimeoutSec=0
RestartSec=2
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

tshoot

docker system df
docker events
docker events --since=$(date -d "1 week ago" --utc +%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ) | grep -i "what do you searcg here"
systemctl status docker.service
journalctl -u docker.service
journalctl -u docker.service | less
docker port container-name # test ports
docker inspect container-name # inspect container
docker inspect --format='' container-name # get ip
docker inspect --format='' container-name # get image

Docker Kernel Features

Namespaces

Purpose: Provides process isolation by creating an isolated environment for each container. How Docker Uses It: Utilizes namespaces, including PID (Process ID) namespaces, to isolate containers at the process level.

Control Groups (cgroups)

Purpose: Allows resource limiting, prioritization, and isolation of system resources like CPU, memory, disk I/O, and network bandwidth. How Docker Uses It: Leverages cgroups to control and limit the resources allocated to containers, preventing resource contention.

Union File Systems (UnionFS)

Purpose: Combines multiple file systems into a single view, facilitating layered container file systems. How Docker Uses It: Utilizes UnionFS to create container images through layers, optimizing storage space and enabling efficient image distribution.

Seccomp (Secure Computing Mode)

Purpose: Provides a method for specifying a filter for system calls, enhancing security. How Docker Uses It: Implements Seccomp profiles to restrict the system calls available to containers, reducing security risks.

Capabilities

Purpose: Offers fine-grained privileges that can be assigned to processes. How Docker Uses It: Assigns necessary capabilities to containerized processes, minimizing potential security vulnerabilities.

AppArmor and SELinux

Purpose: Mandatory Access Control (MAC) mechanisms that restrict process actions, enhancing security. How Docker Uses It: Configurable to work with security modules like AppArmor or SELinux for an additional layer of security.

Overlay Network Driver

Purpose: Enables communication between containers running on different hosts in a cluster. How Docker Uses It: Implements overlay network drivers to create virtual networks spanning multiple hosts, facilitating distributed container communication.

iptables and IP Masquerading

Purpose: iptables configures Linux kernel packet filtering rules, and IP Masquerading enables Network Address Translation (NAT). How Docker Uses It: Uses iptables for network address translation, allowing containers to communicate externally using the host machine’s IP address.

entry.title: tools/git/delete-all-commit-history-github
entry.content:
Delete all commit history on Github

Deleting the .git folder may cause problems in your git repository. If you want to delete all your commit history but keep the code in its current state, it is very safe to do it as in the following:

1) Checkout

git checkout --orphan latest_branch

2) Add all the files

git add -A

3) Commit the changes

git commit -am "commit message"

4) Delete the branch

git branch -D main

5) Rename the current branch to main

git branch -m main

6) Finally, force update your repository

git push -f origin main

PS: this will not keep your old commit history around

Reference

entry.title: cheatsheet/vim
entry.content:
Cheatsheet vim

Vim, the successor to Vi, was created by Bram Moolenaar in 1991. It aimed to enhance and extend the functionalities of Vi while maintaining compatibility. Vim introduced numerous improvements, including syntax highlighting, multiple undo/redo, visual mode enhancements, and support for various programming languages. One of Vim’s strengths is its extensibility. It supports plugins and has a vibrant community that contributes to its continuous improvement.

Comando Descrição
gg Ir para o inicio do arquivo
G Ir para o fim do arquivo
0 (zero) Para ir para inicio da linha
$ (cifrão) Para ir para o final da linha
vim file.txt Criar ou abrir um arquivo(caso exista)
i Modo de inserção
Insert Modo de inserção
ESQ Sair do modo inserção
a Modo inserção um caractere a frente
I Modo inserção no inicio da linha
A Modo inserção no final da linha
o Modo inserção na próxima linha
O Modo inserção na linha acima
S Apagar linha completa e entrar no modo inserção
u Desfaz ultima alteração(igual crtl + z)
crtl + r Refaz ultima alteração
:w Salvar o arquivo
:wq Salvar e sair do arquivo
:q! Sair sem salvar
:x Salvar e sair do arquivo
ZZ Salvar e sair do arquivo
yy Copiar a linha toda
p Colar a linha copiada
y5y Copiar 5 linhas
dd Recortar a linha
d3d Recortar 3 linhas
ESQ + v Modo visual horizontal
ESQ + V Modo visual vertical
y + w Copia uma palavra
y + 3 + w Copia 3 palavras a frente
x delete
X backspace
:w file-new.txt Salvar arquivo com outro nome(salvar como)
:split another-file.txt Divide a tela em duas
crtl + w + w Alternar entre as divisões de tela
:r /etc/hosts Copiar conteúdo de hosts para arquivo atual
/linux Procurar a palavra “linux” dentro do arquivo
n Procura próxima ocorrência da palavra
? linux Buscar palavra “linux” de baixo pra cima
:%s/windows/linux Troca todas as ocorrências de windows por linux
:%s/windows/linux/g Troca todas as ocorrências de windows por linux(mais de uma por linha)
e! /etc/hosts Mudar para outro arquivo descartando alterações atuais
ESQ + :syntax on Habilita o Highlight(arquivo deve ter extenção)
ESQ + :set nu Habilitar a numeração das linhas
ESQ + :set nonu Desabilitar a numeração das linhas
:ab google google.com.br Criar uma abreviação
:set ai Auto identação
:set noai Desabilitar auto identação
:set visualbell Trocar notificação de som para modo visual
:set ic Buscar no modo ignore case sensitive
:set bg=light Background claro
:set tabstop=4 Tamanho do tab em 4 espaços
:set showmatch Mostrar fechamento de parenteses
:.,$!sort Ordenação alfabética
:.,$!sort | pr -2t Ordenação alfabética em duas colunas
